results.adx_keywords: Pulitzer Prizes;News and News Media;Newspapers;Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings;Archibald, John (1963- );Alabama Media Group;Alabama;Brookside (Ala)
results.title: Father-Son Duo in Alabama Wins Pulitzer, Bucking Headwinds in Local News
results.abstract: John Archibald, who has been a journalist in Birmingham, Ala., for years, was anxious about his son Ramsey’s decision to go into journalism. He needn’t have worried.

media.caption: Ramsey Archibald celebrating with his father, John Archibald, who won the 2018 Pulitzer Prize for commentary in Birmingham, Ala.

results.adx_keywords: Content Type: Personal Profile;Folk Music;Pop and Rock Music;Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming;Nineteen Hundred Fifties;Converse, Elizabeth Eaton (Connie);Greenwich Village (Manhattan, NY);Upper West Side (Manhattan, NY);Manhattan (NYC)
results.title: Before Dylan, There Was Connie Converse. Then She Vanished.
results.abstract: There’s a resurgence of interest in the pioneering singer-songwriter who disappeared when she was 50.

media.caption: Connie Converse in Riverside Park, 1946. It is one of the first known images of Ms. Converse in New York.

results.adx_keywords: Books and Literature;Book Trade and Publishing;Censorship;Race and Ethnicity;Japanese-Americans;Asian-Americans;Discrimination;Education (K-12);Writing and Writers;Book Bans;Tokuda-Hall, Maggie;Imamura, Yas;Warwick, Peter;Scholastic Corporation;United States
results.byline: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
results.title: Asked to Delete References to Racism From Her Book, an Author Refused
results.abstract: The case, involving Scholastic, led to an outcry among authors and became an example of how the culture wars behind a surge in book banning in schools has reached publishers.

media.caption: Maggie Tokuda-Hall declined Scholastic’s offer to license her book, “Love in the Library,” on the condition that she edit her author’s note to remove a description of past and present instances of racism.
media.copyright: Marissa Leshnov for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Social Media;Violence (Media and Entertainment);Computers and the Internet;News and News Media;Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming;Allen, Tex, Mall Shooting (May 2023);Musk, Elon;Wardle, Claire;Meta Platforms Inc;Twitter;Allen (Tex)
results.title: Twitter Criticized for Allowing Texas Shooting Images to Spread
results.abstract: Graphic images of the attack went viral on the platform, which has made cuts to its moderation team. Some users said the images exposed the realities of gun violence.

media.caption: A memorial outside an outlet mall in Allen, Texas, on Sunday, a day after a mass shooting there left at least eight people dead. The attacker was killed by a police officer.

results.adx_keywords: Birds;Birdwatching;Animal Migration;Animal Behavior;Research;your-feed-science;your-feed-animals;Global Warming;Prospect Park (Brooklyn, NY);Rome (NY)
results.title: The ‘Devil Bird’ Lands in New York, With More Likely to Come
results.abstract: Anhingas, water birds with snakelike necks, have turned up in Prospect Park in Brooklyn and far upstate, a sign of shifting ranges for birds from the South.

media.caption: An anhinga, also known as the devil bird, spotted in Prospect Park last month.

results.adx_keywords: Movies;Psychology and Psychologists;Television
results.title: I’m Going to Spoil Your Favorite TV Show
results.abstract: Everyone gets mad about spoilers. But science suggests our concern about spoilers ruining our enjoyment of stories is overblown.

results.adx_keywords: Infrastructure (Public Works);Inflation Reduction Act of 2022;Privatization;New Deal (1930's);Roosevelt, Franklin Delano;Brookfield Asset Management
results.title: Why Are We Allowing the Private Sector to Take Over Our Public Works?
results.abstract: The Inflation Reduction Act will spur the takeover of our infrastructure by private entities, particularly large global asset managers, with likely negative consequences.

results.adx_keywords: Tests (Medical);Prostate Specific Antigen;Men and Boys;Tumors;Cancer;Surgery and Surgeons;Elderly;Age, Chronological;Prostate Gland;Preventive Medicine;New England Journal of Medicine;California;Great Britain;United States
results.title: Too Many Older Men Are Still Screened for Prostate Cancer
results.abstract: Most have low-risk cancers and rarely benefit from treatment, a new study finds. Actively monitoring the condition is often the best choice.

media.caption: Joe Loree wanted to avoid the aggressive treatment for prostate cancer that he had seen his brother and friend undergo, and opted for a more conservative approach called active surveillance.

results.adx_keywords: Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Drones (Pilotless Planes);Defense and Military Forces;Bombs and Explosives;Remote Control Systems;Ukraine;Bakhmut (Ukraine)
results.title: Homemade, Cheap and Lethal, Attack Drones Are Vital to Ukraine
results.abstract: Fighting superior Russian firepower, Ukrainian forces turn off-the-shelf drones into deadly weapons by adapting them to carry explosives.

media.caption: A Ukrainian soldier, Yevhen, left, and his comrade, both from the Adam tactical group, fly their drones from a trench at a frontline position on the outskirts of Ivanivske, in eastern Ukraine in April.
media.copyright: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Slavery (Historical);Names, Personal;Libraries and Librarians;Colleges and Universities;Trinity College (Dublin, Ireland);University of California, Berkeley;Dublin (Ireland)
results.title: A Philosopher and a Slaver, but No Longer a Name on a Library
results.abstract: No one disputes that George Berkeley was among Ireland’s greatest thinkers, but he was also an unapologetic slaver. Now, Trinity College Dublin is taking his name off one of its buildings.

media.caption: Trinity College Dublin has decided to rename its main library.

results.adx_keywords: Federal Budget (US);United States Politics and Government;Law and Legislation;National Debt (US);Republican Party
results.byline: By Margot Sanger-Katz and Alicia Parlapiano
results.title: What Would the G.O.P. Plan Actually Do to the Budget?
results.abstract: The plan declines to make choices on cuts, and with large categories exempted by leadership, that may make implementing the bill even harder than passing it.

results.adx_keywords: United States Economy;Federal Budget (US);International Trade and World Market;Treasury Department
results.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ashley Wu
results.title: We Hit the Debt Limit. What Happens Now?
results.abstract: Lawmakers will need to reach a bipartisan agreement to lift the debt limit. The longer it takes, the more turmoil there could be for the United States and the global economy.

results.byline: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin
results.title: ‘It’s Going to Be a While’: No End in Sight for Hollywood Strike
results.abstract: The writers and entertainment companies remain far apart on several key issues, including money, and the standoff could last for months.
org_facet: Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers

media.caption: One analyst speculated that the writers’ strike could go on long enough to effect the Emmy Awards, scheduled for Sept. 18, and delay the fall TV season.
media.copyright: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

results.title: Corporate Giants Buy Up Primary Care Practices at Rapid Pace
results.abstract: Large health insurers and other companies are especially keen on doctors’ groups that care for patients in private Medicare plans.

media.caption: Nurse practitioner Haley Lynn, left, with patient Nathaniel Brookard, at Oak Street Health in Brooklyn. CVS Health recently bought Oak Street’s fast-growing chain of primary care centers that employ doctors in 21 states.

results.title: Ukraine War Coverage Earns Pulitzers for The A.P. and The Times
results.abstract: Several news organizations won multiple awards, including The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times and AL.com, a site that covers Alabama.

media.caption: A classroom in Bucha, Ukraine, damaged by a Russian attack. Several Pulitzer Prizes were awarded for coverage of the war in Ukraine.

results.title: At Churchill Downs, Humans Failed the Horses Again
results.abstract: Despite recent efforts to make horse racing safer, seven horses died at the track in the lead-up to the Kentucky Derby. Whose fault was it?

media.caption: The 2023 Kentucky Derby will be largely remembered for the amount of horses that died or were scratched from races.
